bug.author: hlncrg
bug.summary: Error when running fairseq-generate with both 'score-reference' and 'print-alignment'
bug.description:
<denchmark-h:h2>üêõ Bug</denchmark-h>
I am running the flag --print-alignment and --score-reference together and getting an error. <denchmark-h:h3>To Reproduce</denchmark-h>
I am following the example 'Jointly Learning to Align and Translate with Transformer Models': <denchmark-link:https://github.com/pytorch/fairseq/tree/master/examples/joint_alignment_translation>https://github.com/pytorch/fairseq/tree/master/examples/joint_alignment_translation</denchmark-link>
I am running the command to generate answers on a test set: fairseq-generate binarized --gen-subset test --print-alignment --source-lang en --target-lang de --path checkpoints/checkpoint_best.pt --beam 5 --nbest 1 --score-reference The error that I get is the following: raceback (most recent call last): File "/usr/local/bin/fairseq-generate", line 11, in load_entry_point('fairseq', 'console_scripts', 'fairseq-generate')() File "/home/hecraig/fairseq/fairseq_cli/generate.py", line 286, in cli_main main(args) File "/home/hecraig/fairseq/fairseq_cli/generate.py", line 38, in main return _main(args, sys.stdout) File "/home/hecraig/fairseq/fairseq_cli/generate.py", line 233, in _main ' '.join(['{}-{}'.format(src_idx, tgt_idx) for src_idx, tgt_idx in alignment]) TypeError: 'NoneType' object is not iterable <denchmark-h:h3>Expected behavior</denchmark-h>
If I understand correctly, I would expect the output to be the alignments given the source and target sentences. <denchmark-h:h3>Environment</denchmark-h>
fairseq Version (e.g., 1.0 or master): master PyTorch Version (e.g., 1.0): 1.6 OS (e.g., Linux): Linux How you installed fairseq (pip, source): pip Python version: 3.6
<denchmark-h:h3>Additional context</denchmark-h>
The command works if either 'score-reference' or 'print-alignment' are not included.

comments.comment:
The issue seems to be with this line:
fairseq/fairseq/sequence_scorer.py
Line 90 in bf06ca7
if attn is not None and torch.is_tensor(attn):
<denchmark-code> if attn is not None and torch.is_tensor(attn): attn = attn.data if avg_attn is None: avg_attn = attn else: avg_attn.add_(attn) </denchmark-code>
Where avg_attn is not given a value since torch.is_tensor(attn) is false.
